titles.title: Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site Study Act of 1999
Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site Study Act of 2000

To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to study the suitability and feasibility of designating the Carter G. Woodson Home in the District of Columbia as a National Historic Site, and for other purposes.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Resources.
Mr. Hansen moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 3201.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 413 - 1 (Roll no. 20).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.
Committee on Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on National Parks, Historic Preservation, and Recreation. Hearings held.

committee.name: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

calendar.text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. Ordered to be reported without amendment favorably.

committee.name: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

action.text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. Reported by Senator Murkowski without amendment. With written report No. 106-322.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 640.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

committee.subcommittee: National Parks, Historic Preservation and Recreation
committee.name: Senate Energy and Natural Resources

bill.summary: 11/2/1999--Introduced. Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site Study Act of 1999 - Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to study and report to specified congressional committees on the suitability and feasibility of designating the Carter G. Woodson Home and headquarters of the Association for the Study of African-American Life and History, located at 1538 Ninth Street, Northwest, Washington, D.C., as a unit of the National Park System.Authorizes appropriations.
